awd_abstract_narration:
Most of the fundamental equations of the physical and engineering sciences are partial differential equations (PDE), of which the most difficult  are nonlinear.  A central goal of mathematics is therefore discovering general principles and methods widely applicable to the many  important strongly nonlinear PDE.  This proposal identifies several classes of interesting such problems: analyzing solutions of nonconvex Hamilton-Jacobi equations (with applications  to dynamical game theory models),  improving  PDE methods for weak KAM theory (to establish connections with classical  dynamics), studying  the regularity of solutions of the  infinity Laplacian equation (a key equation for max-norm variational problems),  and investigating the regularity of solutions to certain strongly nonlinear parabolic systems of PDE.  These various nonlinear equations  have widely differing structure, but are unified as being  accessible to variational, maximum principle and/or energy methods, although usually in certain singular limits.

Understanding the existence, uniqueness and regularity of solutions to nonlinear partial differential equations (PDE), and ascertaining as well their behavior, are fundamental mathematical tasks, which  have  interesting  implications in view of the numerous practical interpretations of these equations. For example, the nonconvex Hamilton--Jacobi PDE is the basic equation for two-person differential games; and so understanding the singular structure of solutions helps directly in the design of optimal strategies. Related applications apply to so-called mean field game theory, a newly developed subject modeling behavior of large populations of competing players. In addition the design of fast and accurate numerical methods   depends  upon detailed understanding of the underlying nonlinear PDE.  Vast experience has repeatedly demonstrated that simple-looking nonlinear PDE, with mathematically natural structure, appear and reappear throughout the  pure and applied sciences.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public:  NSF Grant  DMS-1301661  Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations    Lawrence C. Evans  Mathematics Department, UC Berkeley  September, 2017



 A. Research.   NSF grant  DMS-1301661 supported me (and several of my then PhD students) as we developed new mathematical theory for several interesting  nonlinear partial differential equations (PDE) and ordinary differential equations (ODE).


I list below some  highlights of the research supported by this grant:


(1) Developing new weak convergence and averaging methods. Many important  differential equations have coefficients that become highly oscillatory in various interesting singular limits, and it is fundamental to understand how these oscillations affect the solutions. My then student T. Zhang and I developed some robust new rigorous tools to characterize these high frequency limits in various situations, deriving thereby appropriate ``effective limit equations''.  We apply these ideas as well to give a mathematically clean derivation of ``adiabatic invariants'' for Hamiltonian systems. 


(2)   Asymptotics for reaction-diffusion equations. Complicated models for reaction and diffusion effects in chemical systems can sometimes be modeled by   ``Kramers-Schmolukowski'' type  PDE for an appropriate chemical potential. My then student  P. Tabrizian and I found a really elegant way to derive rigorously the limit equations as the reaction rate is scaled. Our techniquesstrongly generalize and vastly simplify  proofs in a well known paper of Peletier-Savare-Veneroni, and are currently being applied by other researchers, especially for higher dimensional problems. 

 (3) New methods for weak KAM theory. Most dynamical systems have  essentially unpredictable behavior, but so called ``weak KAM theory'' attempts to find regions of integrability within the otherwise chaotic dynamics of Hamiltonian systems. I have continued to make steady progress in this important subject using mainly PDE methods. During the time period of this grant   (i )  I published a paper recording several very interesting new identities for a model Hamiltonian, with applications, and (ii) I have made great advances towards working out the connections between the PDE for certain action functions and the principle solutions of related matrix Riccati equations.


(4) PDE models in mathematical finance and economics.  My former student C. Miller wrote several papers on optimal control theory and PDE  methods applied to financial problems. In addition he, I Yang and I worked out a very  elegant convexity argument that generalizes Sannikov's variational problem for principal/agent problems in economics.  
 B. Education.   The following students have  finished their PhD under my supervision during the course of this NSF grant:  M. Safdari (2014),  T. Zhang (2014), K.Beal (2015),   W- H. Cook  (2015), P. Tabrizian (2016),  C. Kroner (2016),  C. Miller  (2016). In addition, I should note that during this time period I put in a lot of work creating the new Math 10A ,B class at Berkeley, a new and ambitious freshman survey for students in the life sciences.
